title: Worksheet 2: Storing Your Numbers
description: Learn to use variables to store and manipulate data in Python.

problems.title: Your first variable
problems.content: Variables are containers that hold values. Think of them like labeled boxes - you put something inside and give it a name. Let's create your first variable! Here we're creating a variable named 'age' and giving it the value 7. The equals sign (=) assigns the value to the variable.
problems.task: Run the code to see the value stored in the variable.
problems.hint: The variable 'age' holds the number 7.

problems.title: Changing a variable
problems.content: You can change what a variable stores by giving it a new value. Try setting the age to your own age for fun!
problems.task: Change the age to your own age and run the code to see the updated value.
problems.hint: Surely you're less than 100! Change the number to your actual age.

problems.title: Two variables
problems.content: Variables can store different values and be used together.
problems.task: Run the code to see both values printed.
problems.hint: Each print shows the value of one variable.

problems.title: Variables in calculations
problems.content: You can use variables in calculations.
problems.task: Run the code to see the sum of apples and bananas.
problems.starterCode:
apples = 5
bananas = 3
total = apples + bananas
print(total)
problems.hint: Variables work like numbers in math.

rules.solutionCode:
apples = 5
bananas = 3
total = apples + bananas
print(total)

problems.title: Edit the numbers
problems.content: Change the numbers in the variables so the total is 20.
problems.task: Edit the code to make total = 20.
problems.starterCode:
apples = 5
bananas = 3
total = apples + bananas
print(total)
problems.hint: Adjust apples and bananas to add up to 20.

rules.solutionCode:
apples = 12
bananas = 8
total = apples + bananas
print(total)

problems.title: Getting input from the user
problems.content: In this problem, we'll use the get_input() command to get a value from the input text box.
problems.task: There is a box to the right called 'x', enter a number and run the code to see how get_input() works.
problems.hint: When there's only one input box, you can use get_input() without any arguments to get its value.

problems.title: Calculating with input
problems.content: Now let's do a calculation with the user input. We can use the input value in math operations just like any other number.
problems.task: Enter a number and run the code to see the input plus 5.
problems.hint: The input value is added to 5 in the print statement.

problems.title: Modify the calculation
problems.content: Your turn - modify the code to add 10 instead of 5 to the user input.
problems.task: Edit the code to print the user input plus 10 instead of plus 5.
problems.hint: Change the 5 to 10 in the print statement.

problems.title: Double the input
problems.content: Now you'll write code from scratch! Write a program that gets a number from the input and doubles it. Remember to use *2 for multiplication.
problems.task: Write code from scratch that doubles the user input.
problems.hint: Use get_input() to get the number, assign it to a variable, multiply by 2 using *2, then print the result.

problems.title: Square the input
problems.content: Squaring a number means multiplying it by itself. For example, 5 squared is $5 × 5 = 25$. In the program, we can write this as x*x.
problems.task: Write code from scratch that squares the user input.
problems.hint: Use get_input() to get the number, then multiply it by itself using x*x.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input()
result = x * x
print(result)

problems.title: Print input twice
problems.content: Let's create a simple example where we print the user input twice.
problems.task: Enter a number and run the code to see it printed twice.
problems.hint: The same variable is printed twice.

problems.title: Multiple calculations
problems.content: Now let's do multiple calculations with the same input. We'll print the input, then input+5, then input+10.
problems.task: Write code from scratch that prints x, x+5, and x+10. You can look at previous questions for help.
problems.hint: Get the input, then use three print statements: one for x, one for x+5, and one for x+10.

problems.title: Adding two inputs
problems.content: Now let's get two numbers from the input boxes and add them together. We'll use get_input() twice to get both numbers. By default, get_input() will return just the value of the first input box, so we need to use get_input('x') and get_input('y') to get the values of the first and second input boxes respectively. The string input into get_input() is the name of the input box.
problems.task: Input 2 numbers and run the code to see the sum.
problems.starterCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x + y
print(result)
problems.hint: Use get_input('x') to get the first number and get_input('y') to get the second number.

problems.title: Make the sum 10
problems.content: Now let's use the same code but you'll fill in the inputs so the output adds up to 10.
problems.task: Fill in the inputs so the output is 10.
problems.starterCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x + y
print(result)
problems.hint: Choose two numbers that add up to 10.

problems.title: Fix the input bug
problems.content: The value passed to the get_input() call must be the label on the input area. Can you see and fix the bug in this code?
problems.task: Run this code to see the error, then fix the bug in the second get_input() function call so the program works correctly.
problems.starterCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('a')
result = x + y
print(result)
problems.hint: Look at the input labels and make sure the get_input() calls use the correct names, the second one uses 'a' instead of 'y'.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x + y
print(result)

problems.title: Multiplying two inputs
problems.content: Now let's modify the code to multiply the two numbers instead of adding them. You'll need to change the operation from addition to multiplication.
problems.task: Edit the code to multiply the variables instead of adding them.
problems.starterCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x + y
print(result)
problems.hint: Change the + to * to multiply instead of add.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x * y
print(result)

problems.title: Divide two inputs
problems.content: Now let's write code from scratch to divide two inputs. Try lots of different inputs once you have the program working!
problems.task: Write code from scratch that divides the first input by the second input.
problems.hint: Use get_input('x') and get_input('y') to get the numbers, then divide using /.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
result = x / y
print(result)

problems.title: Add three inputs
problems.content: Let's take it up a notch! Now we'll work with three input boxes.
problems.task: Write code from scratch that takes 3 inputs and adds them all together.
problems.hint: Use get_input('x'), get_input('y'), and get_input('z') to get all three numbers, then add them together.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
z = get_input('z')
result = x + y + z
print(result)

problems.title: Multiply three inputs
problems.content: Now let's multiply all three inputs together.
problems.task: Write code from scratch that takes 3 inputs and multiplies them all together.
problems.hint: Use get_input('x'), get_input('y'), and get_input('z') to get all three numbers, then multiply them together using *.

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
y = get_input('y')
z = get_input('z')
result = x * y * z
print(result)

problems.title: Powers of a number
problems.content: In math, when we multiply a number by itself, we call it a 'power'. For example, 5 squared (5²) means 5 × 5 = 25, and 5 cubed (5³) means 5 × 5 × 5 = 125. Let's create a program that shows all three: the original number, the number squared, and the number cubed!
problems.task:
Write a program that takes one input and prints three lines: the original number, the number squared, and the number cubed.

Try different input numbers like 2, 3, 5, 0.5, and even negative numbers to see what happens!
problems.hint: First get the input with get_input('x'). Then use three print statements: one for the original number, one for x * x (squared), and one for x * x * x (cubed).

rules.solutionCode:
x = get_input('x')
print(x)
print(x * x)
print(x * x * x)

problems.title: Area of a square
problems.content: So far we've used simple variable names like 'x'. But good programmers use descriptive names that explain what the variable represents! For a square, we'll use 'side_length' instead of 'x' to make our code clearer. The area of a square is found by multiplying the length of one side by itself. For example, if a square has sides of 5 units, its area is 5 × 5 = 25 square units.
problems.task: Write a program that calculates the area of a square. Use the descriptive variable name 'side_length' for the input.

inputs.name: side_length
inputs.label: Enter the length of one side of the square:

problems.hint: Use side_length = get_input('side_length') to get the input, then multiply it by itself using side_length * side_length to calculate the area. Notice how 'side_length' is much clearer than 'x'!

rules.solutionCode:
side_length = get_input('side_length')
area = side_length * side_length
print(area)

problems.title: Perimeter of a square
problems.content: Great! Now let's calculate the perimeter of a square. The perimeter is the total distance around the square - you add up all four sides. Since all sides of a square are equal, the perimeter is 4 times the length of one side. For example, if a square has sides of 5 units, its perimeter is 4 × 5 = 20 units.
problems.task: Write a program that calculates the perimeter of a square. Use the descriptive variable name 'side_length' for the input.

inputs.name: side_length
inputs.label: Enter the length of one side of the square:

problems.hint: Use side_length = get_input('side_length') to get the input, then multiply it by 4 using side_length * 4 to calculate the perimeter. Remember, perimeter = 4 × side length!

problems.title: Rectangle area and perimeter
problems.content:
Now let's work with rectangles! A rectangle has two different sides - length and width. The area is length × width, and the perimeter is 2 × (length + width).

Why 2 × (length + width)? Imagine you have to walk all the way around a rectangular room - you walk one length, then one width, then another length, then another width. So you walk length + width + length + width = 2 × (length + width).

For example, a rectangle with length 6 and width 4 has area = 6 × 4 = 24 and perimeter = 2 × (6 + 4) = 2 × 10 = 20.
problems.task: Write a program that calculates both the area and perimeter of a rectangle. Use descriptive variable names 'length' and 'width' for the inputs. Print the area on the first line and the perimeter on the second line.

inputs.name: length
inputs.label: Enter the length of the rectangle:

inputs.name: width
inputs.label: Enter the width of the rectangle:

problems.hint: Get both inputs using get_input('length') and get_input('width'). Then calculate area with length * width and perimeter with 2 * (length + width). Print both results!

rules.solutionCode:
length = get_input('length')
width = get_input('width')
area = length * width
perimeter = 2 * (length + width)
print(area)
print(perimeter)

problems.title: Creative challenge
problems.content: Write a program using one input & do something cool. Be creative! Show your teacher your code and your output.
problems.task: Create a program that takes one input and does something interesting with it. You can use any of the concepts you've learned: variables, calculations, multiple print statements, etc.
problems.hint: Try combining different operations! You could calculate the input plus 5, minus 3, times 2, divided by 2, etc. Or create a pattern with multiple print statements.
